events.originalText: A natural-gas pipeline in San Bruno, California, exploded and "shot a fireball more than 1,000 feet (300 m) in the air", killing eight people.
events.subtitle: Natural gas
events.headline: Gas pipeline explosion in San Bruno, California kills eight

events.originalText: The first banknotes of the Portrait Series of the Singapore dollar were introduced by the Board of Commissioners of Currency.
events.subtitle: Singapore Portrait Series currency notes
events.headline: Singapore introduces new banknotes in Portrait Series

events.originalText: Imagine, the second solo album by John Lennon (pictured), was released.
events.subtitle: Imagine (John Lennon album)
events.headline: John Lennon's album 'Imagine' released

events.originalText: Allegheny Airlines Flight 853 collided in mid-air with a Piper PA-28 Cherokee flown by a student pilot near Fairland, Indiana, destroying both aeroplanes and killing all 83 occupants of both aircraft.
events.subtitle: Allegheny Airlines Flight 853
events.headline: Mid-air collision near Fairland, Indiana kills 83

events.originalText: An earthquake registering 6.7 Mw struck near Chlef, Algeria, killing over 1,200 people and forcing the government to implement comprehensive reforms in building codes.
events.subtitle: 1954 Chlef earthquake
events.headline: Deadly earthquake strikes near Chlef, Algeria

events.originalText: World War II: About 3,000 Polish Army troops began a nearly month-long defence of the Hel Peninsula during the German invasion of Poland.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Polish Army defends Hel Peninsula during German invasion

events.originalText: At the Lick Observatory in California, Edward Emerson Barnard discovered Amalthea (pictured), a moon of Jupiter and the last natural satellite to be discovered by visual observation.
events.subtitle: Lick Observatory
events.headline: Amalthea moon of Jupiter discovered by Barnard

events.originalText: French Revolutionary Wars: A naval engagement between French and British fleets off the coast of Sumatra ended inconclusively.
events.subtitle: French Revolutionary Wars
events.headline: French and British fleets engage off Sumatra coast

events.originalText: The commissioners overseeing the construction of the United States' new capital city named it Washington, D.C., in honor of the first president.
events.subtitle: Washington, D.C.
events.headline: Washington, D.C. named as new capital city

events.originalText: The Stono Rebellion, at the time the largest slave rebellion in the Thirteen Colonies of British America, erupted near Charleston, South Carolina.
events.subtitle: Stono Rebellion
events.headline: Stono Rebellion erupts near Charleston, South Carolina

events.originalText: Ottoman wars in Europe: A large Croatian army intercepted Ottoman forces returning to the Sanjak of Bosnia, but was defeated.
events.subtitle: Ottoman wars in Europe
events.headline: Croatian army defeated by Ottoman forces

events.originalText: Byzantine forces defeated Achaean troops at the Battle of Saint George, taking control of the Arcadia region of Greece.
events.subtitle: Byzantine Empire
events.headline: Byzantine forces take control of Arcadia region

events.originalText: Yelü Dashi, the Liao general who founded the Qara Khitai, defeated Seljuq and Kara-Khanid forces at the Battle of Qatwan, near Samarkand in present-day Uzbekistan.
events.subtitle: Yelü Dashi
events.headline: Liao general Yelü Dashi wins Battle of Qatwan

events.originalText: After disposing of all relatives who possibly held a claim to the throne, Constantine II, Constantius II and Constans became Roman co-emperors.
events.subtitle: Constantine II (emperor)
events.headline: Constantine II, Constantius II, and Constans become Roman co-emperors

events.originalText: During the Germanic Wars, an alliance of Germanic tribes led by Arminius engaged Roman forces at the Battle of the Teutoburg Forest, defeating three legions within a few days.
events.subtitle: AD 9
events.headline: Germanic tribes defeat Roman forces at Battle of Teutoburg Forest
